items.title: Recurive Cookiecutters ? Moar Cookies !
items.body:
* Cookiecutter version: 1.6.0
* Template project url: https://git.manaikan.com/opensource/biscuits.git
* Python version: 3.6/7?
* Operating System: Windoze

### Description:

I am trying to leverage the fact that Cookiecutter is smart enough to checkout different branches against the `post_gen_hook`.
Ideally this would work as follows :

1) Fire up Cookiecutter against the master branch of ones cookiecutter
2) Provide a choice in the branches' cookiecutter.json that allows the user to select another branch
3) Process the cookiecutter as per usual 
4) Within the `post_gen_hook`  invoke cookiecutter against another branch of the same repository that the user selected in step 2; repeat from step 2 (and it is cookies all the way down.)

By carefully creating the branches such that not two paths overlap it ought to be possible to build up a project where one can selectively pick and choose the components they are interested in; with a little parsing it might be possible to do more then this (I'm thinking leo like file generation here but haven't tried).

From my first attempt it seems that pulling down the second branch is clobbering the download of the first branch both. That is both branches are downloaded into cookiecutter/Biscuits.

### What I've run:

```

['__annotations__', '__builtins__', '__cached__', '__doc__', '__file__', '__loader__', '__name__', '__package__', '__spec__']
You've downloaded C:\Users\USER\.cookiecutters\biscuits before. Is it okay to delete and re-download it? [yes]:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "c:\python\64bit\362\lib\shutil.py", line 391, in _rmtree_unsafe
    os.rmdir(path)
PermissionError: [WinError 32] The process cannot access the file because it is being used by another process: 'C:\\Users\\USER\\.cookiecutters\\biscuits'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\USER\AppData\Local\Temp\tmp0iyqbbq9.py", line 43, in <module>
    overwrite_if_exists=True)              # We are clobering the directory we just created and need to be able to override what is there

    clone = prompt_and_delete(repo_dir, no_input=no_input)
  File "c:\python\64bit\362\lib\site-packages\cookiecutter\utils.py", line 111, in prompt_and_delete
    rmtree(path)
  File "c:\python\64bit\362\lib\site-packages\cookiecutter\utils.py", line 42, in rmtree

### What I'd like

I'm hoping there is some hidden flag I can leverage to either control where the cookie cutter resides e.g. having hierarchically named branches and having the cookies downloaded to hierarchically organized folders under cookiecutter/biscuits would be first prize. 

Otherwise it seems I have two options :

 * Override the config file and replacing `cookiecutter_dir` 
 * Switch to cookie cutter folders instead (Perhaps this was their original intention ?).

items.title: subset of choices renders as a string
items.body:
* Cookiecutter 1.7.2
* https://github.com/2bndy5/Rainmeter-Cookiecutter/tree/import-layout-or-skin
* Python 3.8
* Windows 10

### Description:

I'm trying to provide a different set of "choices" based on user input to prior choices.
Specifically, I've written a post script that imports files/folders based on the user's choice. I want to expand that feature to offer the user choices from `cookiecutter._installed['Skin']` or choices from `cookiecutter._installed['Layout']` based on a previous choice `cookiecutter.import_type`. I'm able to fetch the correct list, but it renders the whole list like a string instead of a list of choices. I've been banging my head against a wall for almost 2 days, so here we are...

### What I've run:

my cookiecutter.json (only the applicable parts for this issue's simplicity):
```
{
    "_installed": {
        "Skin":  [
            "Create a new skin",
            "Goo-e",
            "illustro",
            "Ipod Nano 6g",
            "LCARS Door"
        ],
        "Layout":  [
            "@Backup",
            "Goo-e & LCARS",
            "XMB"
        ]
    },
    "import_type": ["Skin", "Layout"],
    "import": "{{ cookiecutter._installed[cookiecutter.import_type] }}",
}
```

my output:
```
Select import_type:
1 - Skin
2 - Layout
Choose from 1, 2 [1]: 1
import [['Create a new skin', 'Goo-e', 'illustro', 'Ipod Nano 6g', 'LCARS Door']]:
```

I've been playing with generators, jinja2-style for and if loops... It is always the same. the whole list is rendered as a string instead of a subset of choices. Is what I'm trying to currently possible? If not I'm open to workarounds.

items.title: 🏁 automate cookiecutter release pipeline

labels.name: CI/CD
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to the project CI/CD update or fix.

items.body:
We need to automate the release process of cookiecutter, so anyone that can createa tag/release on github repository will trigger a build that publishes the package on pypa.org. This is key in order to allow the project to move forward with lower maintenance efforths and not to lag behind.

In order to achieve this there are few tasks needed:
* [x] create `cookiecutter` bot user on pypa and put the logo on gravatar
* [ ] add `cookiecutter` bot user to pypa as `maintainer`
* [ ] change `cookiecutter` email and credentials to be one where multiple maintainers have access (in case we need to reset credentials)
* [ ] add cookiecutter tokens on travis config
* [ ] update `.travis.yml` with release (deployment) code that runs on tag pushes (@ssbarnea)
* [ ] make the first pre-release or release using this process

Related to this is the proposal that I made to switch-to release-drafter and rely on github release pages instead of maintaining an in-repo file. Still, that proposal is not blocker for automating the process.

items.title: slugify jinja filter (PR provided)
items.body:
* Cookiecutter version: 1.7.0
* Template project url: https://github.com/inveniosoftware/cookiecutter-invenio-rdm/pull/61
* Python version: 3.6
* Operating System: OS X

### Description:

This is a **Feature Request**, **Already implemented**... Just **Asking if it makes sense to do a PR**.

### What I've run:

In order to slugify project names and so on the documentation suggests using the `replace` filter. This works great for simple cases (spaces, etc.). However, the input comes from the user a can be whatever... Therefore for example:

`Pablo's version` will become `pablo's-version`. Having a single quote there can be dangerous since this value will be user maybe in strings and so on... Therefore, I've create a Jinja2 extension that uses the *python-slugify* library (See implemented code here: https://github.com/inveniosoftware/invenio-cli/pull/123/files). This would result in `pablo-s-version`.

If it makes sense I will provide a PR.

* Cookiecutter version: 1.7.0
* Template project url: -
* Python version: 3.8.2
* Operating System: Arch Linux

### Description:

Hi! I'm packaging python-cookiecutter for Arch Linux.
After package build and before installation (that is still during packaging) I'm running `pytest -v`.
The tests `test_cli_extra_context_invalid_format` and `test_should_raise_error_without_template_arg` fail due to slight changes in the output formatting (in click I assume).

This can be fixed with:

```
diff -ruN a/tests/test_cli.py b/tests/test_cli.py
--- a/tests/test_cli.py	2019-12-21 19:29:52.000000000 +0100
+++ b/tests/test_cli.py	2020-03-14 11:53:20.505357215 +0100
@@ -390,7 +390,7 @@

items.title: ModuleNotFoundError when running cookiecutter with pyenv on OSX
items.body:
* Cookiecutter version: 1.7.0
* Template project url: https://github.com/drivendata/cookiecutter-data-science.git
* Python version: 3.6
* Operating System: OSX

### Description:

Running
```
cookiecutter https://github.com/drivendata/cookiecutter-data-science.git
```
results in an error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/cookiecutter", line 6, in <module>
    from cookiecutter.__main__ import main
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'cookiecutter'
```

I think this is related to the shebang in `/usr/local/bin/cookiecutter`. Replacing that with a more generic

```
#!/usr/bin/env python
```
solved the problem for me.

Would it make sense to make this change? Happy to submit a PR.

items.title: News. Development and release plan.

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to or includes documentation.

items.body:
Two weeks ago I was given full permissions to this repository, as well as to readthedocs and pypy. 
I see that there is a very small interest in this project from developers, so several things will be changed soon. This is an announcement about these changes.

1. At the Sunday version `1.7.0` will be released to pypy. It will be the current master, with maybe some not-code related changes.
2. This will be the last release with full code reviews from several core committers. Just because it delays development.
3. The final release of `1.7.x` expected on December 31. Only bugfixes for  `1.7.0` will be reviews at this time. 

New year plan.

The history of this project shows two things.
1. It is self-full at this moment. I.e. it does the thing that supposes to do at this moment. All problems have some kinds of workarounds.
2. Waiting for a sponsor is non-effective.

So the decision:

Let's make something new. With honor and respect to the past.

1. From January 1st and later master branch will include new changes that can be non-compatible with the old version but should introduce new functions.
2. Fixes for the old version will be included in new releases of `1.7.x`, but only bugfixes for confirmed bugs will be included. All new development should be made in the new version `2.0.x`
3. Contributors list for versions 1.x and 2.x will be separated in the documentation.
4. Templates links will be removed from the main master page, as we cannot control templates live and security. I will try to create issue at every template branch, how to implement correct keywords for GitHub search.
5. Most of the issues and pull requests will be closed or merged to 2.0.0 without waiting for contributors. Only live work should be at issues/pr page.

Feel free to comment on this issue. Every thought will be included in the development plan.

items.title: Documenting cookiecutter with sphinx can't handle environment variables in config file
items.body:
* Cookiecutter version:
* Template project url:
* Python version:3.6
* Operating System:Mac Os ()

### Description:
I am trying to get sphinx running to document my django project built with cookiecutter but it seems like sphinx has trouble reading the environment variables in the settings file. 
### What I've run:
When running ```make html``` sphinx gives me problems reading the config file. It says django.core.exceptions.ImproperlyConfigured: Set the USE_DOCKER environment variable

When not calling django.setup() it also throws me an error with my envs: django.core.exceptions.ImproperlyConfigured: Set the POSTGRES_DB environment variable When I hardcode them, the error goes on to complain about the next environment variable. I can't hardcode them all into the config file, that is not an option.

My environment variables are properly configured. When I print them out running my localhost they are there. It seems that somehow sphinx cannot process them. I am also using docker, so maybe that could interfere but I don't know.

My relevant sphinx settings 

```
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath('..'))
os.environ['DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE'] = 'config.settings.local'
```

Parts of my config
```
DATABASES = {
    # 'default': env.db('DATABASE_URL'),  # This was the default value, but modification below seemed necessary
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.postgresql_psycopg2',

# django-extensions

INSTALLED_APPS += ['django_extensions']  # noqa F405

```
I also asked on SO: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58992192/

Thanks for any help! And thanks for Cookiecutter, it's fantastic!

items.title: proposal: replace template listing with a link to github topic

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to or includes documentation.

labels.name: question
labels.description: User questions

items.body:
I would like to propose to remove the [a-pantry-full-of-cookiecutters](https://github.com/cookiecutter/cookiecutter/blob/master/README.rst#a-pantry-full-of-cookiecutters) section from `README.rst` with a simple link to https://github.com/topics/cookiecutter-template

There are few reasons which made me propose this:

* Never-ending source of PRs which can hardly be evaluated without being biased
* Even if a template is good today, it may become broken or unmaintained tomorrow
* Out current list of templates already contains many outdated ones
* There is risk that someone would use the feature to promote malicious templates, amost impossible to catch, especially as they could change the template after inclusion

Advantages for outsourcing it:
* Github has a powerful browser with filters and sorting
* People can evaluate how popular templates are based on their starts
* We can focus on more important PRs
* Nobody could say that we refused on template in favour of another
* 134 repositories are already using the **[cookiecutter-template](https://github.com/topics/cookiecutter-template)** topic

Disadvantages
* Template creators would need to use GitHub to host them or to mirror their repositories on GitHub, which is not really a bit deal, OpenStack does it anyway.

Please use up/down thumbs to vote on this, or add comments with more details. I only hope we do not plan to build a database to list them.

items.title: Choice options are redundant using cookiecutter with latest click package
items.body:
* Cookiecutter version: 1.6.0 -- installed via `pip install`
* Template project url: n/a
* Python version: 3.7
* Operating System: Windows 10

### Description:

If cookiecutter.json has the following:
```json
{
  "my_choice": ["a","b"]
}
```
Then running cookiecutter gives the following prompt:
```
Select my_choice:
1 - a
2 - b
Choose from 1, 2 (1, 2) [1]:
```

Note how the choices are repeated twice in the last line. This is because the [Click API](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/7.x/api/) has been updated to 7.0 and automatically shows the choices to the user in parentheses. This is redundant. 

### Solution
The text passed to the `click.prompt` function should be changed to set `show_choices = False` or it should be changed to not show the choices and let the Click API do so instead.

items.title: Migrate template changes
items.body:
### Description
Oftentimes many projects are instantiated using a given cookiecutter template. During the lifetime of the projects the template is updated and these changes should be migrated to all the instantiated projects.
Keeping up to date with versions and architecture changes is a good example (f.e. rename pep8 to pycodestyle/black in the template and all instantiated projects, etc.).

### Pull Request
PR: https://github.com/audreyr/cookiecutter/pull/1133
Documentation: https://github.com/audreyr/cookiecutter/pull/1133/commits/29f0ccb132031c10f697dd12ad031e38b5cadd09#diff-e1aabcf37538ff8605c16fc241e4dded

### Proposed implementation:
- given a commit in the template repository
- create a patchfile in the source repository (containing the placeholders)
- render the patchfile using the context
- apply the patchfile in the target directory (or save it for manual application)

### Example:
- Having created a python package: `cookiecutter https://github.com/audreyr/cookiecutter-pypackage.git`
- Bugfixes/Changes/Features are introduced in the template
- Migrate the changes: `cookiecutter cookiecutter-pypackage --replay --cookie-pick <commit hexsha>`

### Open points:
- Dependency on gitpython
The pull request currently uses gitpython, but it's entirely possible to write our own diff/apply functions in the vcs.py
- Dependency on git
Currently it only works with git repositories. We could probably use diff/patch as well, but I'm not sure, if that's a common use case.
- Getting the context
Reapplying the context for the cookie-pick is a bit cumbersome. It works well with the `--replay` flag, but it's not really the use case to only reiterate the last run. It's possible to save the context in a file and use it though for now. I presume, that we could save the initial context in the target folder, if prompted (something like `--preserve-context`), but I'll create a separate ticket for that.

items.title: cookiecutter unit test failures with Click 7.0
items.body:
* Cookiecutter version: 1.6.0 (latest master branch)
* Template project url: N/A
* Python version: Any version supported by Cookiecutter
* Operating System: Tested on macOS

### Description:

When running cookiecutter unit tests using the latest master branch, there are two test failures that occur with the latest version of Click (7.0). These failures do not occur with the previous version of Click (6.7). The failures happen with any of the Python versions supported by cookiecutter.

Travis-CI tests of the latest master branch are currently passing because they were last run 11 days ago, prior to the Click 7.0 release. I suspect rerunning Travis-CI will reproduce the failing tests described below.

The two failing tests assert usage error messages raised by Click. In Click 7.0, the argument's `metavar` parameter is displayed in the error message instead of the argument's `name` (https://github.com/pallets/click/pull/612). It appears that the metavar parameter defaults to the argument's uppercased name.

Fixing the tests should be straightforward to support Click 7.0 in addition to older versions. One potential fix is to assert that the *case-insensitive* error message matches what's expected. I'm happy to issue a PR to fix the tests.

Add encrypted pypi password to travis.yaml file. The suggested command  (`travis encrypt --add deploy.password`) in the docs has a poor user experience and caused problems on Windows. Suggested improved user experience by switching to:

items.body:
* Cookiecutter version: git
* Template project url:
* Python version: 3.5.3
* Operating System: Mac


After creating initial django cookiecutter code, I got the following error

InvalidTemplateLibrary
Invalid template library specified. ImportError raised when trying to load 'debug_toolbar.templatetags.compat': cannot import name 'url'
/Users/test/anaconda/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/template/backends/django.py in get_package_libraries, line 125
/Users/test/anaconda/bin/python

IT seems that this line from the django-debug_toolbar has problem:
lib/python3.5/site-packages/debug_toolbar/templatetags/compat.py
from ..compat import url as url_compat

items.title: Any doc for creating iOS Template?
npm and ipython widgets
items.body:
* Cookiecutter version: 1.6.0
* Template project url: https://github.com/jupyter/widget-cookiecutter.git
* Python version: 3.6
* Operating System: Windows

### Description:

Hello,

I just have a question: I want to build an ipython widget, but I don't want to create an account on NPM, can I just host the stuff locally still I'm ready to push everything out to the world?  Also, NPM takes forever to package, what is the best way to speed up using node build?

items.title: cookiecutter output_dir as part of context

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a feature request.

items.body:
My ultimate goal is to change project's name depending on the context (root folder). In particular, I want to index my projects automatically, basing on the max number of matching folder names in the root, like:

```
cookiecutter.N = len(glob(root_dir + '/p2017_12_*')+1
```

However, there are two obstacles to that, from what I can see:
- there is no way currently how I can change `context` from the hook. however, I hope that I can just rename the folder with `sys` in post_gen_hook as a quick-n-dirty solution.
- at the moment, there is no way my hook can see project directory, as it is never introduced as part of the context. It sounds like a simple fix, which I am going to purpose in the following PR

items.title: Choice Variables remove spaces/newlines
items.body:
* Cookiecutter version: 1.3.0 - 1.6.0
* Template project url: https://github.com/thornycrackers/cookiecutter-newline
* Python version: 3.6.2
* Operating System: mac/Arch linux

### Description:

I'm trying to write a cookie cutter and use the choices to render conditional content. My issue is that when cookie cutter renders the project it is removing all of the white space and I the final version ends up ending up on the same line.

```
This is my text.

{%- if cookiecutter.project_type == "option1" -%}

option 1

{%- else -%}

option 2

{%- endif -%}
```

but whenever I run cookiecutter I end up getting

```
This is my text.option 1
```

I couldn't find anything in the docs about this, it's possible I missed it, but is this the intended behavior?

items.title: Python 3.3 support
items.body:
Hey there! 👋 

I just pinned our test dependencies to use ``pytest<3.3.0`` via 0c92f3c893f558d3d5a4f8cb5bf5a3cfb894261d as the [latest pytest release][pytest release] dropped support for Python 3.3.

How do you feel about Python 3.3 support in Cookiecutter?

@audreyr @pydanny @michaeljoseph @pfmoore 

[pytest release]: https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/changelog.html#pytest-3-3-0-2017-11-23

items.title: Trouble deploying Extra context example using the Advanced Usage docs

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to or includes documentation.

labels.name: question
labels.description: User questions

items.body:
I am having difficulty running  the **Advanced example Defaults + Extra Context**, using the [docs](http://cookiecutter.readthedocs.io/en/latest/advanced/suppressing_prompts.html#advanced-example-defaults-extra-context).

I have created a minimal reproducible example using [this project](http://cookiecutter.readthedocs.io/en/latest/first_steps.html#learn-the-basics-of-cookiecutter-by-creating-a-cookiecutter).

```
$ mkdir cookiecutter-fabric-esneor
$ cd cookiecutter-fabric-esneor
$ mkdir {{cookiecutter.directory_name}}
$ cd {{cookiecutter.directory_name}}
```

Here is my `cookiecutter.json`:

```
    {
    "fabric_type": "Vbox",
    "username": "Tom Smith",
    "user": "{{cookiecutter.username.lower().replace(' ','')}}",
    "timestamp": "{{cookiecutter.timestamp}}"
    }
```

Here is my `cookiecutter_runner.py` (based on [this](https://github.com/audreyr/cookiecutter/blob/b2f7ab5041919b27411a278547916424168a0250/docs/advanced/injecting_context.rst)):

```
from cookiecutter.main import cookiecutter

from datetime import datetime

cookiecutter(
    'Hello',
    extra_context={'timestamp': datetime.utcnow().isoformat()}
)
```

My tree is (based on [this layout](http://cookiecutter.readthedocs.io/en/latest/advanced/hooks.html#using-pre-post-generate-hooks-0-7-0)):

```
$ cd ~
$ tree
cookiecutter-fabric-esneor/
├── {{cookiecutter.directory_name}}/
    └── {{cookiecutter.directory_name}}.sh
└── cookiecutter.json
└── cookiecutter_runner.py
```

This is the contents of `{{cookiecutter.directory_name}}.sh`:

```
#!/bin/bash
echo "{{cookiecutter.timestamp}}"
```
When I run

```
$ cd ~
$ cookiecutter cookiecutter-fabric-esneor
```

I get this:

```
fabric_type [Vbox]:
username [Tom Smith]:
user [tomsmith]:
directory_name [fab_dir]:
Unable to render variable 'timestamp'
Error message: 'dict object' has no attribute 'timestamp'
Context: {
    "cookiecuttter": {
    .
    .
    .
    "timestamp": "{{cookiecutter.timestamp}}"
    }
}
```

It's a pretty basic project and I've followed the documentation instructions but it seems like something is missing in the `{{cookiecutter.directory_name}}` directory.

Is there another page in the documentation that has a full example of how to use the Extra Context?

* Cookiecutter version: 1.6.0
* Python version: 2.7.14
* Operating System: Ubuntu 17.10

EDIT: I hope you don't mind me adding the 2 proposed labels to the title. I thought it would be helpful when reading this post.

`cookiecutter.json` is missing: `"directory_name": "fab_dir"`
